channel.title: Traffic correlation using netflows
channel.description: I'm using VPN > Whonix Gateway > VPN connection. I need exit VPN connection in my country. My */usr/local/etc/torrc.d/50_user.conf* config - (StrictNodes 1 ExcludeNodes { my country code }). Additionally, I'm using Noisy (github /1tayH/noisy) on Workstation. If government in my country will have access to exit VPN сan they use traffic correlation using netflows attack for de-anonymize me? (blog torproject /traffic-correlation-using-netflows)

item.title: Traffic correlation using netflows
item.dc:creator: ccc0dy
item.description:
Thank you very much for support!

Read full topic

item.title: Traffic correlation using netflows
item.dc:creator: HulaHoop
item.description:
ccc0dy:

VPN > Whonix Gateway > VPN connection

That first VPN is especially useless at best and a waste of bandwidth and performance handicap.

ccc0dy:

(StrictNodes 1 ExcludeNodes { my country code })

No. You really shouldn;t mess with Tor’s path selection, you will harm your anonymity.

ccc0dy:

I’m using Noisy (github /1tayH/noisy) on Workstation

Another useless measure that wastes resources. Creating chaff to hide the wheat is a more complex problem then simplycontinuously generating bogus traffic. Website fingerprinting would make it trivial to figure out that the requested data is the same fake request. Recent padding implementation in Tor intelligently sends padded cells in just the right amount to obscure traffic from malicious Tor nodes while not wasting bandwidth. Noisy is redundant at best.

ccc0dy:

If government in my country will have access to exit VPN сan they use traffic correlation using netflows attack for de-anonymize me?

If Tor is not broken then no. Most likely they will track you down thru your payment info.

ccc0dy:

blog torproject /traffic-correlation-using-netflows

Is a known problem with known solutions that are being implemented at the moment.

Read full topic

item.title: Traffic correlation using netflows
item.dc:creator: micky
item.description:
Control over the Entry (ISP) + Exit (VPN in your case) is certainly risky for users.

ccc0dy:

Additionally, I’m using Noisy

This might just make you even easier to fingerprint.

Read full topic
